topic.title: Critical Vulnerability in Zeronet?
topic.body:
So the idea of Zeronet is decentralized internet for prevention of censorship, right?  But users can update their own sites, and all other hosts accept the update unconditionally.  In addition, a website's address is a user's public Bitcoin key, which presents a problem.

Let me illustrate with an example: user Bigfoot creates a child porn site (G-d forbid).  Law enforcement wants to shut down the site, but shutting down one of the hosts will not solve the problem.  What do they do?  They use Bigfoot's public Bitcoin key to reverse engineer the identity of Jane Doe, who they then "convince" to "update" their site by removing all the images.  Then anyone hosting the site will automatically update their version to exclude the images.  Law wins, game over.

Am I wrong about this?  am I missing something?  Because if not, there's a simple solution: have each site provide a mandatory changelog/reversion button.  That way, if someone has their blog forcibly taken own this way, then other hosts can revert back to the version they choose, and censorship is no longer as easy as described.

Feedback would be appreciated.  I would say constructive feedback, but of course I can't force anyone here to be nice, so say what you will.

topic.title: Suggestion Regarding Cross-Site Blocking
topic.body:
this is either a better answer to the privacy problem caused or a really good laugh because I have little to no idea of what I'm talking about.

Ok so as I understand it, zeronet sites are no longer allowed to access other zeronet sites to address privacy/security concerns, but this causes problems with things such as zeronet search engines.  Solution?  "Public" and "Private" resources.  Al resources are private by default, but uers can (at their peril) enable public access to certain parts of their site.

I have no idea if this would solve the problem or even if it would work.  It's just a suggestion.

> [nofish](#comment_981_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): There is no such thing as "They use Bigfoot's public Bitcoin key to reverse engineer the identity of Jane Doe". The only attack vector is the Tor connection security, but if anyone can defeat that part, then then can do the same with the new site address.But it's a good idea to create backup on sites you want to save for the future.

what I mean is if Jane Doe has her bitcoin public key posted elsewhere along with her identity or clues to it, all they have to do is google search the key.  And you are correct, there are other ways to reverse engineer someone's identity, I just used that as an example.
